This report was prepared by Loh Ai Tee, Senior Project Economist, Agriculture,

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Country Assistance Plan (2001–2003) included an advisory technical assistance 
(TA) for agribusiness development linked to the Agriculture Program Loan II. The TA was 
confirmed by the Country Program Confirmation Mission in December 2001 and changed to a 
project preparatory TA.1 This was reconfirmed by the Country Program Mission in March 2002. 
This TA paper is based on the work of the Fact-Finding Mission that visited Pakistan from 21 
October to 8 November 2002, to hold discussions with stakeholders and reach agreement with 
the  Government  on  the  TA  objectives,  scope,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and 
implementation arrangements.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The agriculture sector accounted for about 25% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 
2001/02, about 44% of the labor force, and approximately 70% of export earnings. During the 
past decade, the agriculture sector grew at an average annual rate of about 3.5% compared 
with 4–5% previously, due primarily to low productivity and profitability. Total cropped area is 
about 22 million hectare (ha) of which about 18 million ha is irrigated. Average farm size is 
about 4 ha. About 20% of all farmers control almost 40% of the cultivated area. Some 80% of 
the farms are owner-operated, with the remainder farmed by sharecroppers. A summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 1.  
 
3.  The traditional crops (cotton, wheat, rice, sugarcane, and maize) account for 40% of 
agricultural GDP. Production and marketing systems for these crops are fairly well developed. 
Each crop, however, has specific quality problems that need to be addressed, ranging from 
contamination  of  cotton  to  genetic  purity  in  Basmati  rice  to  lack  of  uniformity  in  wheat. 
Production, processing, and marketing systems for minor and horticultural crops are much less 
developed. The organized food-processing industry faces difficulties in procurement of a reliable 
supply of appropriate quality raw materials as well as severe price fluctuations. Product losses 
are substantial at all levels. Inadequate enforcement of quality and sanitary standards at the 
production and local marketing levels also significantly constrains growth of exports. Lack of 
quality seed is a major constraint on increasing agricultural productivity, although the private 
sector seed breeding industry is beginning to develop.  
 
4.  The  agribusiness  sector  comprises  production;  supply  enterprises  (seed,  fertilizer, 
pesticide,  machinery,  and  equipment);  traders;  processors;  exporters;  and  various  service 
providers (crop contracting, transportation, storage, shipping, etc.). The various elements of the 
agribusiness system vary considerably in sophistication and organization. The agrochemical 
subsector is made up of several large firms engaged in fertilizer, pesticide, and seed production 
and distribution. The agroprocessing industry is dominated by large cotton-based spinning, 
weaving, textile, and garment manufacturing enterprises, followed by sugar, wheat, and rice 
milling as well as beverages and processed foods. The food-processing segment of the industry 
is characterized by a few large operations, primarily indigenous, and a host of small and cottage 
enterprises that are largely free from government intervention. 
 
5.  Agribusiness has the potential to become a substantially greater source of economic 
growth  and  income  generation,  with  small-scale  farmers  as  major  beneficiaries.  Although 
Pakistan has a comparative advantage in the production and export of high-value and other

nontraditional crops, this potential is not generally being translated into significant competitive 
advantage at the firm and farm level, primarily because of inadequate postharvest facilities and 
generally poor infrastructure. Other constraints include adverse policies, ineffective institutions, 
and  varying  approaches  to  regulation  of  product  quality  by  the  federal  and  provincial 
governments. Some of the policy issues such as restrictions in trade of agricultural commodities 
and commodity support prices and subsidies are being addressed under Loan 1877–1879-
PAK(SF): Agriculture Sector Program Loan II.2 Issues of governance and access to credit will be 
addressed in the financial sector and small- and medium-sized enterprises in projects under 
preparation. The proposed Agribusiness Development Project will complement these projects in 
enhancing the business environment through capacity building and institutional reforms. 
 
6.  The recent move to form commodity boards, and the increasing number and strength of 
producer organizations are encouraging signs for agribusiness development. The boards (with 
representation from the Government and various private sector segments of the concerned 
industries) primarily aim to provide a unified voice and support mechanisms for the various 
commodity subsectors. Commodity boards have been established for horticulture and dairy. 
Although not specifically for agriculture, the Export Promotion Bureau (EPB) and the Small and 
Medium Enterprise Development Authority were established to promote business development 
and exports. Several strong industry associations are also active in providing support and 
advocacy for their commodity subsectors. The Rice Exporters Association of Pakistan is an 
example of a private sector organization assuming the responsibility of ensuring uniformity in 
quality and standards. 
 
7.  In preparing the TA, extensive consultation was carried out with federal and provincial 
government  agencies,  all  segments  of  private  sector  stakeholders,  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and funding agencies. The Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Livestock 
(MINFAL) prefers a project focused on a specific subsector, while other subsectors that warrant 
support could be taken up as separate projects. The provincial governments prefer separate 
projects, coordinated with the federal Government as poor performance may harm overall 
project implementation. The separation of federal and provincial responsibilities should be 
considered  in  recommending  project  implementation  arrangements.  Lessons  were  also 
considered from past projects, which have generally suffered delays and cost underruns and 
overruns for various reasons, including deficiencies in project design due to inadequate time 
and  resources  for  project  preparation.3  To  ensure  against  repeating  these  deficiencies, 
emphasis on institutional strengthening and more effective use of consultants and counterpart 
staff have been recommended. Experience with the implementation of the Agriculture Program 
Loan suggests that policy and other reforms that have political and social implications need to 
be carefully assessed to determine government commitment and implementation capacity.4 
Such reforms should be carried out on a gradual, phased basis. 
 
8.  Given the complexity of agribusiness and the large number of actors, from farm input 
suppliers to exporters, the Project will be small and focused primarily on the agribusiness 
system of one or two commodity subsectors while addressing a few selected problem areas in 
other commodities. The general  consensus is that horticulture (fruits, vegetables, and cut 
flowers and/or foliage) should be accorded first priority. Even within the horticulture sector, 
however, the Project should focus initially on a limited number of commodities that exhibit the

most promise for profitable growth and which are selected on the basis of market analysis, 
supply chain, competitive advantage, and potential profitability. Horticulture products warrant 
support as they represent the most immediate prospect for enhancing value addition, increasing 
exports, and raising farm family incomes. Fruit exports between 1990 and 2000, for example, 
grew by 114% in volume and 342% in value, although total production of the major fruits 
increased by only 22%. Export of vegetables and floriculture products has good potential. 
Export  expansion,  however,  is  constrained  by  the  lack  of  functional  cold-chain  systems; 
inadequate supply of the proper quality and varieties of seed and planting materials, particularly 
for vegetables; lack of proper packing materials; poor transport conditions; and generally low 
and variable productivity of horticultural crops. Although a fairly rigorous system of inspection 
and certification is used at export points, product sanitary and quality measures vary greatly at 
provincial  levels.  The  growth  of  the  horticulture  export  sector  will  require,  and  facilitate 
development of, the domestic marketing system for horticulture products. The Government of 
Switzerland is supporting a project to promote horticulture, and the project can build upon the 
experience gained and lessons learned. 
 
9.  Pakistan is the world's sixth-largest producer of milk, and the dairy industry has potential 
for growth. A large number of small-scale farmers participate in the industry, which is primarily 
based on smallholders. Constraints include low levels of productivity due primarily to inferior 
breeding stock combined with lack of adequate feeding materials, and the deterioration in 
quality  that  occurs  during  handling  and  transport  from  producer  to  consumers.  The  dairy 
subsector will not receive the same emphasis as horticulture, and proposed interventions will be 
focused on handling, processing, and value addition, where maximum benefits can be realized.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The  purpose  of  the  TA  is  to  help  the  Government  design  a  private  sector-led 
agribusiness development project. The TA output is a feasibility study that includes (i) a detailed 
evaluation of the agribusiness sector; (ii) proposed strategies to develop different subsectors; 
(iii) recommended areas, subsectors, and crops for future development; and (iv) formulation of a 
project to develop agribusiness.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will be undertaken in two phases. The first will involve a detailed assessment of 
agribusiness sector potential and constraints. The assessment will include (i) a review of 
existing studies and the traditional farming systems, with particular emphasis on those that 
include nontraditional crops such as fruits and vegetables, and processing of dairy produce, and 
their role in agribusiness development; (ii) a review of efficiency of water utilization by the 
different cropping systems and its impact on the environment, taking into consideration the 
findings of TA 3130-PAK: Water Resources Strategy; (iii) a comparative advantage analysis of 
different  crops;  (iv)  the  distribution  system  for  inputs;  and  (v)  processing,  handling,  and 
marketing of outputs. The assessment should include a systematic analysis of the relevant 
institutions  for  input  supply,  production,  and  marketing  (including  research,  development, 
extension,  marketing,  and  commodity  boards)  to  determine  their  effectiveness  and 
responsiveness to industry needs. The analysis will also include the policy, legal, and regulatory 
frameworks affecting the agribusiness environment as well as the appropriate roles of the 
federal and provincial governments and the private sector. The analysis will lead to identification 
of (i) different strategies to develop agribusiness in mature and emerging subsectors; (ii) the

4      
subsectors and commodities demonstrating rapid growth potential for agribusiness development 
in the short and medium term; (iii) the subsectors that warrant further study; (iv) the potential for 
separate projects or project components at the provincial level; and (v) necessary policy, legal, 
and institutional reforms.  
 
12.  Based on the findings of the first phase, the second phase will involve formulation of a 
project for agribusiness development with emphasis on value addition. The proposed project 
should be broad based to provide maximum benefit to small-scale farmers and enterprises. 
Benefiting small-scale farmers will, however, also require active participation by the entire 
agribusiness system. The proposed Project should act as a catalyst and introduce facilitating 
mechanisms to enable establishment of effective agribusiness systems by the various private 
sector stakeholders and define the areas where the Government can play a supporting role. The 
proposed  Project  should  promote  increased  private  sector  participation  and  facilitate  the 
establishment  of  linkages  among  all  of  the  agribusiness  stakeholders  to  improve 
responsiveness to the changing domestic and international markets. Strengthening and capacity 
building will be carried out for selected public and private institutions and organizations to 
ensure that they play an effective role in agribusiness sector development. The project design 
will also include policy, legal, and institutional reforms to enhance productivity and efficiency, 
and create an enabling environment to improve the competitiveness of agriculture. The outline 
terms of reference for consulting services are in Appendix 2. 
 
 13.  The  first  and  second  phases  are  envisaged  to  take  3.5  months  and  2.5  months, 
respectively, during which close consultation with federal, provincial, and district governments 
as well as private sector stakeholders, including farmers, traders, processors, middlemen, 
marketers, and exporters will be carried out at all stages. Farmer organizations and NGOs will 
be consulted to explore means of involving them in the Project. Private stakeholders will also be 
involved in the initial assessment and project formulation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total TA cost is estimated at $876,000 equivalent, comprising $452,000 in foreign 
exchange costs and $424,000 equivalent in local currency costs. The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $248,000 equivalent of the local 
currency costs for a total of $700,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from 
ADB's TA funding program. The Government will finance the remaining local cost of $176,000 
equivalent. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. The Government 
has been informed that TA approval does not commit ADB to finance an ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MINFAL is the Executing Agency for the TA and responsible for coordinating with the 
relevant federal and provincial departments and agencies as well as providing logistical support 
to the TA consultants. MINFAL has appointed a full-time counterpart to assist the Mission in 
overall coordination and support. The Mission requested that the counterpart staff continue in 
this capacity throughout the TA and project implementation. The Government assured ADB that 
(i) requisite support staff in addition to the counterpart will be provided to support the TA 
consultants; (ii) appropriate transportation will be provided for counterpart staff and consultants; 
(iii) office space, utilities, furnishings, and local communication facilities will be provided for the 
consultants and counterparts; and (iv) assistance will be provided for surveys, stakeholder 
workshops,  and  participatory  workshops.  A  steering  committee  will  be  established  with

5 
representatives  from  the  federal  and  provincial  agencies  to  provide  guidance  to  the  TA 
consultants and will meet as required. 
 
16.   A total of 44.5 person-months of consulting services, comprising 17.5 person-months of 
international and 27 person-months of domestic inputs, are required. International consultant 
expertise will be required in institutional, agribusiness, financial market, horticulture, and dairy 
industry aspects. Domestic consulting expertise will be required in institutional, agriculture 
marketing,  economics  and  financial,  horticulture  industry,  dairy  industry,  social,  and 
environmental aspects. Provision is also made for an additional 3 person-months of short-term 
assignments for experts drawn from local industry. A consulting firm or consortium of firms will 
be selected in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants using the quality- 
and cost-based selection method and other arrangements satisfactory to the ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants. The simplified technical proposal procedure will be used to select the 
consulting firm.  
 
17.  The  TA  will  commence  in  May  2003  and  be  completed  in  November  2003.  The 
consultants will be based in Islamabad and travel extensively nationwide for consultation. They 
will conduct workshops at inception and at the end of the first and second phases at the 
provincial  and  federal  levels  to  obtain  feedback  from  the  Government  and  private  sector 
representatives  and  other  stakeholders.  The  consultants  will  also  conduct  participatory 
workshops for farmers and entrepreneurs, local community groups, farmers' organizations, and 
NGOs to solicit their views. The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 4 weeks of 
commencement, outlining the work program, methodology, and relevant preliminary findings; (ii) 
an interim report at the end of the first phase setting out the detailed sector assessment, 
proposed strategies, and proposed subsectors; (iii) a draft final report setting out the feasibility 
study for a proposed project within 5.5 months of commencement; and (iv) a final report within 
0.5 month after submission of the draft final report. Tripartite meetings among the Government, 
ADB, and TA consultants will be held after submission of the inception, interim, and draft final 
reports. There will be a month's break between the first and second phase for ADB and the 
Government to further study and reach agreement on the consultants' recommendations. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 to the Government 
of Pakistan for preparing the Agribusiness Development Project, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board. The technical assistance, initially financed as a grant, will be subject to the 
reimbursement arrangements set forth in Technical Assistance Operations5 and Streamlining of 
Technical Assistance Operations.6 If the technical assistance results in an ADB loan, ADB may 
charge against the loan, and recover from it, the portion of the initial grant that exceeds 
$250,000 equivalent.

and promote economic growth. 
Contribution of the sector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
About 75% of the poor in Pakistan live in rural areas, a proportion of whom are pushed into poverty because of income 
volatility. The agricultural sector accounted for about 25% of GDP in 2001/02, employs about 44% of the labor force, 
and accounts for approximately 70% of export earnings. Over 95% of the employed rural population depend on 
agriculture  for  their  livelihood  either  directly  or  indirectly.  Comprising  production  input  enterprises,  farmers  and 
producers, traders, processors, exporters, and various service providers, agribusiness has the potential to become a 
much more important source of economic growth and income generation, with small farmers as major beneficiaries. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis            Economic Growth 
Rural Poverty. Poverty is widespread but has historically been higher in rural than urban areas. Pakistan has no official 
poverty lines and, as a result, several poverty studies have all used different figures. The Federal Bureau of Statistics 
(using the expenditures necessary for intake of 2,550 calories as the poverty line) reported incidence of poverty in 1998-
1999 at 32% overall and at 36% in the rural areas. Poverty incidence has probably risen since then, due to the decline 
in growth of nonfarm activities and in public sector development spending. Inequality also increased during the 1990s. 
Although growth in agriculture averaged 3.5% per  year during the past 10 years, the incidence of rural poverty is 
estimated to have increased by over 7% in the same period. Pakistan does not have gender-disaggregated poverty-
related data. However, various studies show that women bear a disproportionately high share of the burden of poverty 
within the family and society. Women’s access and control over productive resources is extremely limited. Women’s 
mobility is restricted and gender segregation and female seclusion are common. Poverty is characterized by economic 
vulnerability (households do not have diversified sources of income to smooth out consumption expenditure in response 
to exogenous shocks) and social vulnerability (denial of basic rights, social exclusion, corruption, manipulation of 
regulatory controls, and insecurity). The poor also have low education, large households, and few physical assets, and 
rely disproportionately on informal sector jobs.  
 
Rural Poverty and the Agriculture Sector. One of the root causes of rural poverty is heavy dependence on 
agriculture, which has been marred by low growth in the last decade. Over the last 3 years the agricultural sector has 
grown at an annual rate of about 1.8%, significantly lower than the average growth rate of over 4% observed in the 
1980s and most of the 1990s. Due to a dearth of other opportunities in the agricultural sector, the impact of low 
agricultural growth on the rural economy was severe and incomes declined and unemployment and underemployment 
increased. The reasons for low agricultural growth are multidimensional and include low productivity and profitability, 
distorted commodity markets, weak research and extension services, and lack of an agribusiness system. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis: The TA will involve participation of stakeholders at different levels and from different sectors, 
including government, production input enterprises, farmers and producers, traders, processors, exporters, and various 
service providers. Farmers, women, and the rural poor will be active participants. The Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and 
Livestock; Ministry of Commerce; provincial governments; and various research institutions and extensions will be 
actively involved.  
Participation strategy required. Yes. 
The TA implementation will follow an integrated participatory approach. Involvement of stakeholders from various levels 
and sectors will ensure that the approach is adhered to. An important aspect will be the participation of the target 
population in project formulation, planning, implementation, and monitoring.

Appendix 2  8 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants will carry out a feasibility study for a private sector-led agribusiness 
development project. The first phase of the study will entail a detailed assessment of the 
agriculture and agribusiness sector, efficiency of water resources utilization under the land 
tenure and farming systems, impact of such utilization on socioeconomic conditions and the 
environment, and agribusiness development opportunities and constraints. The assessment will 
include the roles and performance of public and private sector institutions and organizations and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), with the objective of building on successful agribusiness 
development initiatives by already-existing institutions. The assessment will also examine the 
legal, regulatory, and policy framework affecting agribusiness and horticulture. Based on this 
evaluation,  the  consultants  will  recommend  (i)  strategies  for  development  of  different 
subsectors, with emphasis on value addition; (ii) subsectors and/or commodities in which 
Pakistan has a comparative advantage and which should thus be the focus of the project; (iii) 
subsectors/commodities  with  potential  for  future  development,  which  warrant  further  study 
leading to possible future projects; (iv) roles and responsibilities for the public and private 
sectors, including the delineation of roles and responsibilities of federal, provincial, and district 
governments;  (v)  potential  to  develop  separate  projects  at  the  provincial  level;  and  (vi) 
necessary changes in the policy, legal, and institutional framework. 
 
2.  The second phase will entail formulation of a project to act as a catalyst and introduce 
facilitating  mechanisms  to  enable  establishment  of  effective  agribusiness  systems  by  the 
various private sector stakeholders. The second phase will focus on (i) the rationale and 
objectives of the proposed project, (ii) the scope and project components as well as the 
stakeholders and project beneficiaries, (iii) estimated project cost, (iv) benefits accruing to the 
stakeholders and beneficiaries, (v) project viability and the associated risks, and (vi) social and 
environmental  impact  of  the  project.  The  project  design  should  incorporate  the  necessary 
changes in policy, legal, and institutional framework, and the assistance and capacity building 
required  for  these  changes.  The  report  should  include  a  logical  project  framework  and 
arrangements for procurement and monitoring and evaluation. 
 
3.  A  total  of  17.5  person-months  of  international  and  27  person-months  of  domestic 
consultant  inputs  are  required.  International  consulting  expertise  will  be  required  for  the 
institutional (6 person-months), agribusiness (6 person-months), financial markets (1 person-
months),  horticulture  industry  (3  person-months),  and  dairy  industry    (1.5  person-months) 
aspects. Domestic consulting expertise will be required for the institutional (6 person-months), 
agriculture  marketing  (5  person-months),  economics  and  financial  (4  person-months), 
horticulture industry (3 person-months), dairy industry (3 person-months), social (3 person-
months), and environmental (3 person-months) aspects. Provision is also made for an additional 
3  person-months  of  short-term  assignments  for  experts  drawn  from  local  industry.  The 
international and domestic institutional specialists will be a team leader and deputy team leader. 
The specific terms of reference for the first and second phases are as follows. 
 
A.  Institutional Aspects

dealing  with  agriculture,  small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises,  agribusiness, 
horticulture, and livestock to determine their performance, reasons for success or

B.  Agribusiness Aspects  
 
5.  The consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Rapidly assess the agribusiness sector, from input distribution and production to 
processing, handling, marketing, and exports, to identify subsectors with the 
greatest potential for growth, documenting specific issues and constraints in each 
subsector and recommending remedial measures. 
(ii)  Review  the  Government's  development  strategies,  policies,  and  regulatory 
framework pertaining to agribusiness and horticulture; determine how they affect 
the agribusiness sector; and recommend reforms. 
(iii)  Identify  the  key  constraints  on  adoption  of  new  technology  by  farmers, 
processors,  and  marketers,  and  the  responsiveness  of  each  group  to  new 
technology. 
(iv)  Identify the commodities with the greatest potential for domestic and export 
markets and identify factors that limit or enhance their development.

private sector. 
(ix)  Determine the need for commodity marketing studies and a needs assessment of 
key value chain elements for selected commodities. 
(x)  Determine the need to provide quality control equipment, and training in its use. 
(xi)  Determine the type and extent of support that might be provided to current 
initiatives aimed to develop industry-owned integrated farm service enterprises.  
 
C.  Marketing Aspects  
 
6.  The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Examine the supply-and-demand situation and trends for each crop/commodity in 
the domestic market while taking into consideration competition from imports. 
(ii)  Examine the market structure for the different commodities in the international 
market to identify the major foreign competitors, evaluate current and future 
demand for exports, and estimate attainable market share. 
(iii)  Assess the effectiveness of market information and market intelligence systems 
and facilities and recommend measures for improvement. 
(iv)  Identify the key quality issues in traditional crops and recommend assistance to 
overcome these issues. 
(v)  Assess  the  status  of  postharvest  and  marketing  systems  and  facilities  and 
recommend improvements. 
(vi)  Examine internationally accepted quality control programs such as International 
Standard Organization, hazard analysis and critical control points, and others, 
and recommend measures to enable the agriculture and agribusiness sector to 
qualify for certification under these programs. 
(vii)  Analyze the implications for the agriculture and agribusiness sector of the various 
consumer-related, retailer-led product quality and social certification programs, 
including Fair Trade, EuropGap, and similar initiatives, and determine measures 
to prepare the agribusiness sector to meet these program requirements. 
 
D.  Financial Market Aspects  
 
7.  The consultants will (i) review the financial markets and assess their ability to meet the 
requirements for agribusiness-related activities; (ii) assess the role of public and private sector 
credit and financial institutions in providing credit facilities to traders, processors, and other 
participants in the marketing system; (iii) recommend alternative means to meet the capital 
requirements of the agribusiness sector.

Appendix 2  11 
E.  Social Aspects  
 
8.  The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review past and present agriculture and rural development projects, their impact 
on the beneficiaries' social welfare, lessons learned, and mechanisms to reach 
small farmers and vulnerable groups. 
(ii)  Conduct participatory workshops with farmers, agribusiness workers, and other 
stakeholders to gain an insight into how the land tenure and farming systems 
affect the social conditions of the different segments of the farming community, 
and  their  access  to  resources  (financial  and  technical  know-how)  and 
representation in local groups and associations. 
(iii)  Prepare social profiles of the different segments of the farming population to 
determine the best means to reach them and ensure that small-scale farmers 
and vulnerable groups are not left out or adversely affected by the project, and 
develop social safeguard measures. 
(iv)  Prepare a social assessment of the beneficiaries and stakeholders using the 
ADB  Guidelines  on  Poverty  and  Social  Assessment,  identifying  any  special 
characteristics that may require attention. 
(v)  Assess  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  the  area  and  prepare  a  poverty  impact 
assessment for the with- and without-project situation and, if needed, conduct a 
distributional analysis of the impact of the Project. 
 
F.  Horticulture Aspects  
 
9.  The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review  horticulture  industry  development  strategies  and  programs  in  other 
developing countries to apply lessons learned. 
(ii)  Review and assess the production, harvest, postharvest, and marketing systems 
for horticulture crops; identify the primary constraints on them; and recommend 
solutions. 
(iii)  Assess the inputs for horticulture crops, including seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, 
and  any  others,  and  recommend  improved  technologies  and  input  delivery 
systems. 
(iv)  Rapidly appraise the horticulture commodity processing and marketing industries 
and systems and recommend improved approaches and technology. 
(v)  Evaluate training needs and approaches for technicians and farmers. 
(vi)  Evaluate current and prospective international markets for horticultural products 
and recommend strategies to gain access to these markets. 
 
G.  Dairy Industry Aspects  
 
10.  The consultants will (i) review dairy industry development strategies and programs in 
other developing countries to apply lessons learned; (ii) review and assess dairy production and 
dairy product markets and marketing, including present and projected consumer demand and 
product  preferences;  (iii)  based  on  the  above  review  and  assessment,  identify  specific 
constraints on the handling, processing, and marketing of dairy products, and define  those 
areas where these constraints can be addressed through development of postharvest and 
marketing facilities common to several or all perishable food products.

Appendix 2  12 
H.  Commercial Field Crop Aspects  
 
11.  The  consultant  will  identify  the  type  and  cause  of  quality  problems  in  production, 
postharvest handling, and marketing of cotton, rice, wheat, sugarcane, oilseeds, and minor 
crops; analyze the effect of these problems on market acceptance and market value; and 
recommend solutions.  
 
I.  Environmental Aspects  
 
12.  The  consultant  will  (i)  review  the  efficiency  of  water  resource  utilization  under  the 
cropping systems, with due consideration to the findings of TA 3130-PAK: Water Resources 
Strategy, and determine the most efficient crops and cropping systems for water resource 
utilization; (ii) review the environmental impact of crop production systems to identify practices 
that are and will be detrimental to the environment; (iii) evaluate the extent and impact of project 
activities, prepare an initial environmental examination in accordance with ADB’s Environmental 
Assessment Requirements and Environmental Guidelines for Selected Agriculture and Natural 
Resource Development Projects and the country’s guidelines for the environment, recommend 
mitigation measures and monitoring programs taking into account implementation capacity, and 
estimate  the  measures’  cost  and  incorporate  it  in  the  total  project  cost;  (iv)  specify  the 
institutional  arrangements,  necessary  capacity,  and  process  whereby  subprojects  will  be 
subjected  to  environmental  assessment  during  project  implementation,  and  develop 
environmental guidelines and criteria to select potential subprojects for a credit line if a credit 
component is deemed necessary.  
 
J.  Economic and Financial 
 
13.  The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Using  the  domestic  resource  cost  approach,  determine  the  comparative 
advantage of the different crops and agricultural commodities that have growth 
potential in domestic and export markets. 
(ii)  On the basis of the comparative advantage analysis and the agronomic and 
social conditions, identify the subsectors and commodities that the proposed 
project should focus on to realize the greatest benefits to the largest number of 
farmers, the agribusiness sector, and the national economy.  
(iii)  Keeping in view the different credit projects that are being or will be implemented, 
assess  the  credit  needs  of  farmers,  traders,  processors,  and  exporters  of 
agricultural commodities to determine the necessity of a credit component under 
the project. 
(iv)  Should a credit component be deemed necessary, determine the extent of credit 
needs under the project, the list of potential subprojects, selection criteria for 
subborrowers, and the terms and conditions of the credit line. 
(v)  Identify the constraints on farmers' access to credit and examine mechanisms to 
overcome them. 
(vi)  Estimate the cost of the components and the project in foreign exchange and 
local currency equivalent and prepare the financing plan. 
(vii)  Carry  out  economic  and  financial  analysis  to  determine  the  viability  of  the 
proposed Project, and investigate the distribution of the project benefits among 
different stakeholders, especially small-scale farmers. 
(viii)  Undertake sensitivity and risk analyses.
